Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Assessing Paleoclimate Using Ice Age Amphibian and Reptile Communities from Southern Chinese Caves
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will investigate fossil remains of frogs, salamanders, and reptiles from caves in Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in southern China. Research will be conducted in collaboration with cave expert Dr. Changzhu Jin and paleoherpetologist Dr. Yuan Wang at the Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology (IVPP) in Beijing, China. IVPP will provide access to previously-collected cave sediments, including some fossils available for immediate examination and additional fossils to be produced by sediment processing at IVPP during the course of the investigation. These sediments record multiple ice ages as well as the intervening warmer periods. Because amphibians and reptiles have specific temperature and moisture requirements, understanding what animals lived in southern China during these extreme climatic events will aid in reconstructing paleoclimate. Predictions of future climate change utilize paleoclimatic data to generate more robust models to inform mitigation policies for water resource availability and agricultural practices.

The project will investigate fossil herpetofauna from Pleistocene deposits in caves from Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in southern China. Previously collected sediment will be available at IVPP. Some fossils will have already been recovered, and work will begin immediately to identify the remains. Further work will require wet-sieving and screening of sediment, allowing intermittent drying to fully breakdown clays. Recovered bones will be sorted under a microscope according to taxon. Preliminary identifications of all fossil will be made in Beijing; identifications will be confirmed utilizing the modern comparative collection at East Tennessee State University. Environmental requirements of modern taxa will be used to approximate Pleistocene climate in the region. Amphibians are more sensitive to climate change than reptiles, and their range changes can be used to predict the severity of future climate change. Understanding their response to the dramatic changes of the Pleistocene will allow for more robust prediction models. This NSF EAPSI award supports research by a U.S. graduate student and is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My research at the Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology (IVPP) in Beijing, China focused on fossils from caves in the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in southern China. My main interest was in the fossil frogs, salamanders, lizards, and snakes from these caves, which lived during the Pleistocene (the “Ice Ages”). These cave deposits range in age from 2.2 million years old to about 30,000 years old.

While at IVPP, I examined nine caves and found at least one amphibian fossil from each cave. Over 650 specimens were recovered, including at least 280 frog specimens and possibly the first Pleistocene salamander fossils from China. I also identified approximately 160 lizard and 95 snake fossils which included many elements from the skull. Though the lizards and snakes have been studied from these caves, the focus had been on vertebrae and lower jaws which are easier to spot. However, bones from the skull are better for identifying these animals to genus or species.

The specimens are currently on loan to the East Tennessee State University Vertebrate Paleontology Laboratory. East Tennessee State University has an extensive collection of modern skeletons, which will allow me to identify the fossils I recovered more precisely. This university also has a high-quality microscope camera, which I will use to photograph particularly important specimens to include in a publication updating the list of species present in these caves.

Because amphibians and reptiles depend on the environment for their body heat, and because many amphibians require high moisture in order to breathe through their skin, these animals can be very good indicators of past climate. By looking how the animal communities vary among caves of different ages, it may be possible to observe change in time as the climate became warmer or colder between the different Ice Ages. Understanding how amphibian and reptile communities changed in response to past climate change may offer insight on how these communities will continue to react to human-caused climate change. Many of the modern amphibians and reptiles of southern China are poorly understood and poorly studied. They may be very susceptible to extinction. By quantifying how species reacted to past climate change, we can more effectively focus conservation efforts on susceptible species. Data from these caves can also be used in larger paleoclimate models, which can then be incorporated into regional models for future climate change.
